newsitem.title: USA: US Treasuries end higher on benign inflation gauge.
newsitem.headline: US Treasuries end higher on benign inflation gauge.

text.p: U.S. Treasury prices closed higher on Tuesday after the prices component in a closely watched gauge of the nation's manufacturing activity fell.
The prices measure of the National Association of Purchasing Management's (NAPM) March index fell to 50.9 in March from 55.1 the prior month.
That news soothed the market's initial alarm over a jump in the overall NAPM index to 55.0 in March from 53.1 in February. A reading above 50 indicates an expanding economy.
As a result, the bellwether 30-year bond ended up 9/32 at 94-13/32, its yield at 7.08 percent.
At the short end of the maturity curve, three- and six-month bill rates fell two basis points to 5.16 percent and 5.30 percent, respectively.

"The big news today was the price component of the Purchasing Managers report," said Bill Hornbarger, fixed-income strategist at A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. "The headline showing the gain in the overall index gave us a sharp, hard trade down. But when people saw the price index was low, the market immediately popped up."
The perception that the market was somewhat oversold also prompted some short-covering, analysts said.
"A couple of bad shorts helped drive the market along," said one trader.

And of the small burst of optimism that fueled some buying, Credit Suisse First Boston's chief markets strategist Matthew Alexy said, "The market's been down for so long, people see a two-basis-point rally as a big deal."
To move higher, bond investors set aside a 2.3 percent rise in February construction spending and a 0.5 percent increase in the index of leading economic indicators.
And analysts said the credit markets were scarcely in the clear.

Chris Rupkey, vice president and financial economist at Bank of Tokyo/Mitsubishi, said the market faced two months of economic news before the next Federal Reserve policy meeting on May 20. He said investors could not count on those data to make a decisive case for no further interest-rate tightenings.

"Usually the economy has to run into some kind of wall -- either an unknown shock or a high wall of interest rates and I don't think anyone believes that a 5-1/2 percent Federal funds rate will slow things down," Rupkey said.
The Federal Reserve raised its federal funds rate 25 basis points to 5-1/2 percent on March 25.

Alexy, too, said the market had a lot of data to examine between now and the next Fed meeting. In the short-term, jobless claims data for the latest week could hurt the market if the number of claims falls below 300,000, he said. A Reuters poll found economists, on average, estimated that new claims totaled 310,000 in the week ended March 29.
Investors are starting to focus on March payroll data, due Friday. Reuters' poll showed economists, on average, estimated that payrolls grew by 182,000 new jobs in March.
But investors will be concerned if, as forecast, average hourly earnings rise 0.4 percent, Rupkey said.
Traders said there was some buying by investment funds and central banks.
Alexy cited some "shortening trades," in which long paper was sold in favor of the middle of the yield curve.
Year bill rates slipped two basis points to 5.65 percent on Tuesday. Two-year note prices rose 2/32 to 99-23/32, yielding 6.40 percent.
The five-year note climbed 5/32 to 99-19/32 to yield 6.72 percent and the ten-year was up 7/32 at 95-18/32 to yield 6.88 percent.
(( -- N.A. Treasury Desk, 212-859-1679 ))
